title: China completes Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University
description:
In July 2005, the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev when meeting with Chairman Hu Jintao proposed intentions to establish Confucius Institute in Kazakhstan. On December 20, 2006, Hanban and Eurasian national university from Kazakhstan signed a cooperation agreement to establish a Confucius Institute with Xi'an International Studies University become Chinese side’s executive body. In August 2007, Xi'an International Studies University and Eurasian National University signed "Implementation Agreement" of cooperation in the establishment of Confucius Institute and set up a board of directors of Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University.
December 5th, 2007, Confucius Institute at the Eurasian National University held the opening ceremony. Minister of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan Zhanseit Tuimebayev, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the People’s Republic of China in Kazakhstan Zhang Xiyun and representatives of the governments of Kazakhstan and China attended opening ceremony and made a speech. Tuimebaev said, with becoming closer in the political, economic, cultural and other areas of cooperation with China, Kazakhstan will need more and more well-trained Chinese language personnel. Confucius Institute established in Kazakhstan will make a great contribution promoting bilateral cooperation in various fields.
sources: http://www.hanban.org/confuciousinstitutes/node_6835.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kz.chineseembassy.org/rus/zhgx/t389583.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://akipress.com/news:1516/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ic.enu.kz/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=76:-2&catid=40:news&Itemid=90&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://en.people.cn/90001/90781/90879/6316199.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.sina.com/china/1/2007/1205/135360.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: A Confucius Institute was established at Eurasian National University. It is is located in Astanta, which is in the ADM2 of Tselinogradskiy.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: CDB provides a $73 million USD syndicated loan to refinance JSC Lokomotiv's loan
description: In 2014, a group of banks, including HSBC Bank and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $73 million USD syndicated loan to Joint Stock Company (JSC) Lokomotiv to refinance a loan that was previously obtained for the acquisition of 22 electric locomotives. STAFF_NOTE: Because the specific breakdown of this loan syndicate is unknown and it included a non-Chinese institution, the transaction amount has been left blank to avoid capturing non-Chinese financial flows.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/75ixogw7ft00ra0/-3313-i.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.ebrd.com/work-with-us/projects/psd/ktz-local-currency-loan.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.railways.kz/sites/default/files/godovoy_otchet_2013_0.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://dfo.kz/kz/DfoObjects/objects/teaser-view/30917?RevisionId=0&Download=-3313-%D0%B8.pdf&PluginId=30735b3a096446d4adef7ac8c90deecf&ReportId=60234407&ReportNodeId=2, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSC_Lokomotiv , Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: A loan was provided to refinance JSC Lokomotiv's loan to build 22 locomotives. The factory and company are located in Astana/Nur-Sultan so I coded the ADM2.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: Bank of China provides a $49.2 million loan to Kazakhtelecom to purchase Huawei equipment
description:
On April 15, 2009, Kazakhtelecom JSC, Kazakhstan's largest fixed-line telecommunication operator, which is 51% owned by Kazakhstani state-owned National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna, the Bank of China (BOC), and Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. signed tripartite mutual understanding memorandum for the financing of telecommunication development projects in Kazakhstan (see "Kazakhtelecom (Kazakhstan), Bank of China and Huawei Technologies sign three-side memo"). Then, in 2011, BOC loaned Kazakhtelecom $49.2 million USD to purchase Huawei equipment (see pg.12 of "Results as of 2011 and 1Q 2012"). Per the loan agreement, BOC transferred the loan proceeds of directly to Huawei (see pg.49 of "Kazakhtelecom 2011 Annual Report"). Loan details are unknown.

STAFF_NOTE: "Project status" was set to "Completion" because it appears that the entirety of the funds were disbursed. Some sources claim this was a $25.6 million USD in the first half of 2011 (for example, pg.12 of "Результаты за 1 полугодие 2011 года"); in all likelihood, this was the first tranche of this larger loan. Kazakhtelecom reported the loan as ₸7,236,607,00 KZT ($49,344,629.18 in USD-2011 terms), but this transaction amount was not used because official sources reported a USD amount and it is highly unlikely that BOC would directly transfer funds denominated in KZT to Huawei (see this loan amount at pg.49 of "Kazakhtelecom 2011 Annual Report").
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZWIR0020090416e54f001b9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kase.kz/news/show/1071618, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kt.kz/eng/economy/kazakhtelecom_bank_of_china_huawei_technologies_signed_memorandum_of_understanding_1153483286.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://telecom.kz/storage/files/_95/66/5d/64/53/95665d64533b8e02f917f0dbdc0c8b36.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://telecom.kz/epkt/storage/files/_c1/22/82/75/db/c1228275db49553a1ca1649690b98bbb.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://telecom.kz/epkt/storage/files/_7f/4b/16/a6/a5/7f4b16a6a5f7019656a23ea06603c28b.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://telecom.kz/storage/files/_95/66/5d/64/53/95665d64533b8e02f917f0dbdc0c8b36.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://telecom.kz/en/news/view/5781, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Since the loan was given to Kazakhtelecom, I coded to Nur-Sultan since that is where they are headquartered. Nur-Sultan is located in Tselinogradskiy. I was able to fine the coordinates on wikipedia
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $183.95 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 33 km Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #55016)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $183.95 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 33 km Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (also called the 33 km Astana Ring Road Project, the Southwest Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project, or the XH33 Project) (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see rest at "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства...").

China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation (see "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). The project sought to construct the 33 km long southwest bypass of Astana, giving it an asphalt and concrete surface of category I (see pg.38 of "Logistics and Transport Competitiveness in Kazakhstan"). Once completed, the road would allow freight vehicles to travel around the city, reducing urban traffic and enabling the development of of logistics centers and service facilities along the ring road. Construction began in December 2017 and the road was expected to be fully operational by 2019 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). The construction was suspended for a month due to the COVID-19 pandemic; it restarted in May 2020, with an expected handover dating now falling in August 2020 (see "Feature: Ring road construction resumes as Kazakh capital partially reopens").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This project supported the construction of a 33 km southwest section of the ring road (bypass road) around the city of Astana -- from the road to the airport to the M36 highway. Further locational details are provided at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/astana-southwest-bypass-road-construction/38a208f4-305f-4a0c-891b-4ab678753cdd/ and page 38 of http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/trans/publications/Report_-_Kazakhstan_as_a_transport_logistics_centre_Europe-Asia.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 努尔苏丹市西南环城公路. The Kazakh project title is «Астана қаласының айналма жолы». The Russian project title is Строительство автомобильной дороги Юго-Западный обход города Астаны.
sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20180611124851/https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://kz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/t/201807/20180702767861.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sasac.gov.cn/n2588025/n2641611/n4518442/c11103815/content.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.government.kz/en/novosti/1015138-development-of-the-astana-agglomeration-discussed-in-the-government-of-the-republic-of-kazakhstan.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/5d5y0hhe1xy9wuu/KazAvtoZhol_2018_FS_ENG.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://zakon.uchet.kz/rus/docs/P1800000047, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazautozhol.kz/oldweb/images/Investors/KazAvtoZhol_2018_FS_ENG.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/article/i/jyjl/e/201905/20190502867981.shtml , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://adilet.zan.kz/kaz/docs/P1300001409, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://miid.gov.kz/en/pages/implementation-state-program-nurly-zhol, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://zakon.uchet.kz/rus/docs/P1700000201, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/trans/publications/Report_-_Kazakhstan_as_a_transport_logistics_centre_Europe-Asia.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-05/06/c_139035041.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: This project was for the 33 km Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project. It encircles Astana, so I coded its ADM2.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 266 km Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54991, #55016, and #54990)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal highway (also known as the Merke-Shu-Burylbaytal highway) (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see rest at "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства..."). 

The total project cost was approximately $297 million USD; co-financiers are unknown (see "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). The reconstruction of the Merke-Burylbaytal highway was divided into 4 sections totaling 262 km in the Jambyl Region of Kazakhstan. The road section from Merke to Shu, 86 km long, was to be for four-lane traffic. The remaining 3 sections from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal,176 km long in total, was to be for two-lane traffic. The highway was to pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, and Birlik. The project included the construction of six bridges, three overpasses over rail lines, 11 illuminated traffic intersections, 276 culverts, recreation areas, and auto pavilions. The project was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "В Жамбылской области началась реализация..."). China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 26, 2019 (see "新兴建设承建的哈萨克斯坦MB266国家级公路改造项目举行开工典礼").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The official Chinese project name for the road is 梅尔克-布鲁拜塔尔公路改造. The Russian project title is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканско-го значения «Мерке –Бурылбайтал» км 7-273. This project and Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's combined cost was $808 million USD. Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's individual cost of $511 million USD was known. Therefore, to calculate the cost of this project, AidData substracted $511 million USD from $808 million USD and got $297 million USD.
sources: http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/kompaniya-kazavtozhol-podpisala-dvustoronnee-soglashenie-v-ramkakh-foruma-odin-poyas-odin-put, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; title: ICBC provides $300 million USD to refinance notes issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #72865)
description:
JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

To finance the 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, CNODC and KTO contributed $50 million USD of their own funds (as captured by linked project ID#39605; in addition, $600 million USD was raised through the issuing of Eurobonds by JP Morgan Bank (see "Atasu-Alashankou project"). Then, in August 2013, KCP entered into a $300 million facility agreement with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Almaty) JSC (ICBC Almaty) to refinance notes that it had issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project. This loan facility bears interest at a rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 3.75% margin per annum. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $180 million USD (₸59.8 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on this information, interest rate was recorded as 6-month LIBOR in August 2013 (0.395%) + 3.75%, or 4.145%; the maturity and grace periods are unknown.

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The original financing of the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605.

The 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline runs from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China. It passes through the Karaganda, East-Kazakhstan and Almaty regions of Kazakhstan. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/uploads/user_31/2019_30_07__01_08_01__775.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/history?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/atasu_alashankou, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Zhanaarkinskiy, Shetskiy, Aktogayskiy, and Alakolskiy Districts are all coded for this project since the pipeline that was funded for construction runs through all these districts. The location of the pipeline is found on slide 4 of the powerpoint provided in the project description. (Shetskiy)
name: Shetskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 266 km Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54991, #55016, and #54990)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal highway (also known as the Merke-Shu-Burylbaytal highway) (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see rest at "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства..."). 

The total project cost was approximately $297 million USD; co-financiers are unknown (see "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). The reconstruction of the Merke-Burylbaytal highway was divided into 4 sections totaling 262 km in the Jambyl Region of Kazakhstan. The road section from Merke to Shu, 86 km long, was to be for four-lane traffic. The remaining 3 sections from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal,176 km long in total, was to be for two-lane traffic. The highway was to pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, and Birlik. The project included the construction of six bridges, three overpasses over rail lines, 11 illuminated traffic intersections, 276 culverts, recreation areas, and auto pavilions. The project was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "В Жамбылской области началась реализация..."). China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 26, 2019 (see "新兴建设承建的哈萨克斯坦MB266国家级公路改造项目举行开工典礼").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The official Chinese project name for the road is 梅尔克-布鲁拜塔尔公路改造. The Russian project title is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканско-го значения «Мерке –Бурылбайтал» км 7-273. This project and Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's combined cost was $808 million USD. Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's individual cost of $511 million USD was known. Therefore, to calculate the cost of this project, AidData substracted $511 million USD from $808 million USD and got $297 million USD.

name: Merkenskiy

title: China opens Confucius Institute at National Technical University of Karaganda of Kazakhstan
description: In 2011, a Confucius Institute was opened at Karganda State Technical University (KSTU). After an opening ceremony in 2012, the institute promotes Chinese culture and teaching the Chinese language.
sources: http://english.hanban.org/node_42166.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kstu.kz/confucius-institute-of-kstu/?lang=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://global.factiva.com/du/article.aspx/?accessionno=TRENDE0020150323eb3n0012x&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=&cat=a, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: A Confucius Institute was opened at Karganda State Technical University. It is located in Karganda, which is located in Bukhar-Zhyrau District.
name: Bukhar-Zhyrauskiy

title: China Development Bank provides a $100 million USD loan to Chem-Plus LLP for the production of caustic soda in the Chemical Park Taraz Special Economic Zone
description:
In June 2017, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $100 million loan agreement with Chem-Plus LLP to finance the production of caustic soda. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 10 years and an interest of 4.7% per annum (pg.27 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год"). The project had a total cost of ₸47.6 billion KZT (approximately $142.8 million USD in 2017); thus, this project was co-financed (see "Айдын Рахимбаев возглавил ренкинг крупнейших получателей господряда в Казахстане").

The project was located in Chemical Park Taraz Special Economic Zone in the Shu District of the Jambyl Region (see "Astana hosts fourth meeting of Kazakhstan-China Business Council"). The project sought to construct a caustic soda line at the Formulation Complex, intended for the production and sale of plant protection products (herbicides) for the Kazakhstani market (see "Actual projects - Chem-Plus LLP"). It was to be capable of producing 40,000 tons. The commissioning was planned for 2020. Construction had begun by 2017, but it had been suspended until a decision was made on the further implementation of the project's fourth start-up glyphosate complex (pg.34 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год").

A consortium led by Kazakhstani company Construction Corporation Kulager LLP was awarded the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract for the project on November 20, 2017 (see pg.19 of "Chem-plus LLP Financial statements For the year ended 31 December 2018 together with independent auditor's report"). In addition to Kulager LLP, the consortium featured German company Chemieanlagenbau Chemnitz GmbH, Kazakhstani company Promstroyproekt Design Institute LLP and Kazakhstani company Aral Service LLP (pg.8 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год"). The construction was on-going as of December 31, 2018 (see pg.16 of "Chem-plus LLP Financial statements For the year ended 31 December 2018 together with independent auditor's report"). The complex was commissioned in January 2019, but it appears that the caustic soda line had not gone into production (see "Actual projects - Chem-Plus LLP").

The shareholders of Chem-Plus LLP were Kazakh state-owned enterprises: United Chemical Company LLP (99.87% ownership stake) and Samruk-Kaazyna Invest LLP (.13% ownership stake) (see pg.14 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год").

STAFF_NOTE: Chem-Plus LLP is sometimes also called "KHIM-Plus" LLP or ТОО «ХИМ-плюс». Chem-Plus refers to this project in Russian as «Производство каустической соды и хлора» or Проект «Производство каустической соды».

title: CDB provides $2.3 billion USD in debt facilities for the development of Bozshakol and Bozymchak copper deposits - Drawn Down Amount (Linked to Project ID#40241 and #61142)
description:
In December 2009, KAZ Minerals PLC secured debt facilities worth $2.7 billion USD by a loan from China Development Bank (CDB) and JSC Sovereign Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna for the development of copper deposits Bozshakol, Bozymchak and other growth projects. The breakdown of these debt facilities was as follows: $2.1 billion USD signed on December 30, 2009 for Bozshakol, Bozymchak, and other development projects; $200 million USD signed on January 12, 2010 for Bozshakol, Bozymchak, and other development projects; two facilities of $200 million USD each for the Akbastau-Kosmurun and Zhomart projects signed on June 11, 2012. KAZ Minerals and a subsidiary of Samruk-Kazyna, provided a guarantee for these obligations. The funds were fully drawn in January 2013. They attracted interest semi-annually at an annualized rate of USD LIBOR + a 4.80% margin. The loans under this credit line had a final maturity date falling between January 2022 and August 2025. The first repayment commenced in January 2013. The $400 million USD that had been allocated to Akbastau-Kosmurun and Zhomart projects was repaid early, in January 2014, because these projects were unlikely to proceed in the medium term (see pg.53 and 96 of "RELEASE OF FINAL RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2014 AND RESUMPTION OF TRADING").

For the remaining $2.3 billion USD, KAZ Minerals signed an amendment to the debt facilities with CDB and Samruk-Kazyna on December 29, 2014. The changes made by the amendment include the following: the facilities became bilateral between KAZ Minerals and CDB; the interest rate was lowered from USD LIBOR + a 4.80% margin to USD LIBOR + a 4.50% margin; and an arrangement fee of 0.5% was agreed to, of which 60% was paid in December 2014 and 40% was paid in January 2016. The loan’s maturity and grace period were left unchanged; KAZ Minerals PLC continued to guarantee this CDB facility (pg.135 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016" and "Amendment to CDB facilities"). The amount outstanding on the previous facility when the amendment was signed was $2.1 billion USD. As of December 31, 2016, $1.7 billion had been drawn down under the facility agreements. Arrangement fees with an amortised cost of $20 million USD were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39 (pg.135 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016").

To calculate the interest rate at time of commitment, the 6-month LIBOR rate as of December 2009 was used (0.453%); total interest rate equals 0.453% + 4.8%, or 5.253%. The grace period was set to 3 years (as the loan was first contracted on December 30, 2009 and the first repayment began in January 2013), and the maturity period was set to 15.66 years (as the loan was contracted on December 30, 2009 and the final loan maturity date was in August 2025). The bilateral amendment between CDB and KAZ Minerals also clarified the loan proceeds were to be used “principally for the development of the Bozshakol and Bozymchak [mine] projects." As of November 30, 2014, the principal balance outstanding on the facilities was $2.086 billion USD. This project records the transaction amount $2.3 billion USD, as it appears to have been fully drawn down (see "Amendment to CDB facilities").

Bozymchak is an open-pit copper mine and concentrator in Ala-Bukinsky region of the Jalal-Abad Region, Kyrgyzstan. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was the EPC contractor for the Bozymchak mine project (see "NFC In Central Asia"). The completion ceremony for the Bozymchak mine took place on August 5, 2015 (see "Kazakhmys Gold opens new copper, gold and silver mine in Kyrgyzstan"). Detailed locational information about this mine can be found at https://www.mindat.org/loc-297492.html.

The Bozshakol mine is a large copper mine located in the North Kazakhstan Region. NFC was the EPC contractor for the Bozshakol mine project, with a contract valued at $486 million USD. The project sought to establish facilities able to mine 30 million tonnes per year. It was planned to be complete on June 30, 2015. (see "NFC Signs Contract on Bozshakol Copper Concentrator Project with Kazakhmys"). The completion of construction and the commencement of commissioning works was held on September 29, 2016 (see "Bozshakol Clay Plant Completion"). Detailed locational information about this mine can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Bozshakol+Copper+Mine/@51.8469877,74.2913709,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0xee5b22335ffe85b1?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiJ2IKl0ZvpAhV2hHIEHQkhDH0Q_BIwFXoECBEQCg.

name: Ekibastuz

title: [Refinancing] CDB debt facilities for development of Bozshakol and Bozymchak copper deposits (linked to #61056 and #40241)
description: In December 2009, KAZ Minerals secured debt facilities of $2.7 billion loan from China Development Bank and JSC Sovereign Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna for the development of copper deposits Bozshakol, Bozymchak and other growth projects. In January, $400 Million allocated to projects that were unlikely to proceed in the medium term was repaid early. For the remaining $2.3 billion debt, KAZ signed an amendment to the debt facilities with CDB and Samruk-Kazyna in December 2014. The changes made by the amendment include the following changes: the facilities will become bilateral between KAZ Minerals and the CDB, Interest rate lowered from USD LIBOR plus 4.80% to USD LIBOR plus 4.50%, Arrangement fee of 0.5%, 60% payable in December 2014 and 40% payable in January 2016. To calculate the interest rate at time of commitment, the 6 Month LIBOR Rate as of December 2009 is used - 0.453%. Total interest rate = 0.453% + 4.5% = 4.953%. As at 30 November 2014, the principal balance outstanding on the facilities was $2,086 million. This project captures the rescheduling of the debt in 2014. The grace period is 3 years, and the maturity period is between 12 and 15 years. STAFF_NOTE: Transaction value is not recorded as amount is already captured in #61056
sources: https://www.kazminerals.com/repository/news-container/news/2014/amendment-to-cdb-facilities/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Using the website for KAZ Minerals, I was able to find the location of the copper mines. Exact coordinates were checked using google maps.
name: Ekibastuz

title: China Development Bank provides a $400 million USD loan for the 630 MW Third Unit of the Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#66481)
description:
On October 22, 2013, China Development Bank (CDB) and Russia's Vnesheconombank (VEB) signed a $400 million USD loan agreement to finance the construction of the Third Unit of the Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Station in Kazakhstan (see "Eighteenth regular meeting between the heads of the Russian and Chinese governments"). The loan had a maturity period of 10 years; its other terms are unknown. This loan was often lumped together with a $800 million USD CDB loan to VEB for a multifunctional complex in Moscow, signed at the same time (captured by linked project ID#66481), as a "$1.2 billion USD loan" (see pg.50 of "VEB Annual Report 2013"). 

VEB used the proceeds of the CDB $400 million USD loan to on-lend to the "Ekibastuz GRES-2" Joint Stock Company (JSC) for the construction of the third unit of Ekibastuz GRES-2 coal power plant in Ekibastuz. Ekibastuz GRES-2 was a coal-power thermal power plant with an installed capacity of 1 GW, located in the city of Ekibastuz in the north of Kazakhstan (see "3-й энергоблок Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 и др. проекты. Самрук-Энерго озвучил планы на среднесрочную перспективу"). VEB led a consortium, that included the Eurasian Bank of Kazakhstan, were to provide a $700 million USD syndicated loan for the project (see "DEWEY & LEBOEUF REPRESENTS EKIBASTUZ GRES-2 POWER STATION ON A $770 MILLION SECURED FINANCING"). The project had a total cost of $700 million USD (see "China and Russia to spend $400 million on Kazakhstan power plant"). VEB's finances were drained because of its financing of Olympic facilities in Sochi, making it look to CDB to partially finance the project (see "Taming the Dragon: How Can Russia Benefit From China’s Financial Ambitions in the SCO?").

"Ekibastuz GRES-2" Joint Stock Company (JSC), an energy company located in Kazakhstan, managed the plant. Until December 2019, Russian energy company Inter RAO UES owned 50% and Samruk-Energy (JSC) owned 50% of Ekibastuz GRES-2. In December 2919, Samruk-Kazyna JSC purchased the 50% Inter RAO's shares for $25 million USD, transferring the plant entirely to Kazakhstan through the management of Samruk-Energy (JSC). Ekibastuz GRES-2 was a coal-power thermal power plant with an installed capacity of 1 GW, located in the city of Ekibastuz in the north of Kazakhstan (see "3-й энергоблок Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 и др. проекты. Самрук-Энерго озвучил планы на среднесрочную перспективу").

The two existing power units at GRES-2 currently produce about 12% of all electricity produced in Kazakhstan in 2010. The CDB-financed project involved the construction, development and operation of a third unit, which, once completed, would seek to increase the power station’s installed capacity by 50% (see "DEWEY & LEBOEUF REPRESENTS EKIBASTUZ GRES-2 POWER STATION ON A $770 MILLION SECURED FINANCING"). The capacity of the third unit was expected to be 630 MW. Construction began on October 21, 2014. The project was planned to be completed in 2017 (see "На Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 началось строительство 3-го энергоблока").  Construction was apparently delayed in 2016, but it has since returned (see "3-й энергоблок Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 и др. проекты. Самрук-Энерго озвучил планы на среднесрочную перспективу").

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is 3-го блока Экибастузской ГРЭС.

The GRES-2 Power Station (or Power Station Ekibastuz) is a coal-fueled power generating station in the town of Ekibastuz within Pavlodar Region. More detailed locational information can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ekibastuz_GRES-2_Power_Station#/map/0 and https://latitude.to/satellite-map/kz/kazakhstan/15146/ekibastuz-gres-2-power-station and http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/40122 and https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ekibastuz+GRES-2+Power+Station,+Gres-2+140000,+Kazakhstan/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x4257917c05aaeefb:0x1106a87977b9d7ae?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj0uOak1pvpAhVUkHIEHTxjBNUQ8gEwC3oECBQQBg.

title: China donates school supplies to Kazakhstan
description: In May 2017, China donated school supplies to the Hadong people in Kazakhstan. Ambassador Zhang Hanhui met with Anhusai, President of the Association of East Asian People in Kazakhstan in Astana. Through the association, China donated money and 500 sets of textbooks including 2,500 teaching books and 500 reading pens to the Hadong people. The books are meant to teach Chinese to schoolchildren.
sources: http://kz.china-embassy.org/chn/sgxx/sgdt/t1459151.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Kordayskiy and Zhambylskiy districts are coded for this project. Acorrding to the source, the supplies were donated to the Dungan people living in Kazakhstan. The Dungan villages in Kazakhstan were found on a wikipedia page where three villages are mentioned: Masanchi & Sortobe are located in Kordayskiy district and Zhalpak-tobe village is located in the Zhambylskiy district. All three villages can be found using google maps (Kordayskiy)
name: Kordayskiy

title: ICBC provides $300 million USD to refinance notes issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #72865)
description:
JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

To finance the 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, CNODC and KTO contributed $50 million USD of their own funds (as captured by linked project ID#39605; in addition, $600 million USD was raised through the issuing of Eurobonds by JP Morgan Bank (see "Atasu-Alashankou project"). Then, in August 2013, KCP entered into a $300 million facility agreement with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Almaty) JSC (ICBC Almaty) to refinance notes that it had issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project. This loan facility bears interest at a rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 3.75% margin per annum. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $180 million USD (₸59.8 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on this information, interest rate was recorded as 6-month LIBOR in August 2013 (0.395%) + 3.75%, or 4.145%; the maturity and grace periods are unknown.

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The original financing of the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605.

The 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline runs from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China. It passes through the Karaganda, East-Kazakhstan and Almaty regions of Kazakhstan. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/uploads/user_31/2019_30_07__01_08_01__775.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/history?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/atasu_alashankou, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Zhanaarkinskiy, Shetskiy, Aktogayskiy, and Alakolskiy Districts are all coded for this project since the pipeline that was funded for construction runs through all these districts. The location of the pipeline is found on slide 4 of the powerpoint provided in the project description. (Aktogayskiy)
name: Aktogayskiy

title: China completes Al-Farabi Confucius Institute at Kazakh National University
description: On February 23, 2009, the official opening ceremony for the Confucius Institute at the Kazakh National University was held at in the city of Almaty. This institute was formerly known as Kazakh Chinese Language Center since 2002, and it was co-founded by Lazakh National University and Lanzhou University. The name was changed to Confucius Institute in 2007.

title: China Eximbank provides a $400 million USD loan for the Pavlodar Aluminium Smelter Construction Project
description:
In May 2010, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $400 million USD loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the aluminium smelter construction project in Pavlodar. The loan accrued the following terms: a maturity period of 15 years (the maturity date was May 21, 2025) and an interest rate of 4%. The principal and interest were to be repaid semiannually. As of June 30, 2017, the principal amount outstanding under this loan was $324 million USD (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017" and “Information on Kazakhstan Electrolytic plant JSC”). Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation (ENRC) provided a guarantee for the loan, which was reportedly a line of credit (see “Overview of key developments from analysts of Asyl Invest JSC (Kazakhstan) on April 16, 2010”).
 
DBK then used the proceeds of the China Eximbank loan to on-lend to Kazakhstan Aluminium Smelter JSC (KAS) (also known as Kazakhstan Electrolytic Plant JSC), the project company and a subsidiary of ENRC and responsible for the Pavlodar Aluminium Smelter Construction Project. The entire project cost $1.0183 billion USD, and KAS contributed $618.3 million USD (see pg.67 of “Information on Kazakhstan Electrolytic plant JSC” and "Kazakhstan Aluminium Smelter JSC").

The Pavlodar Aluminium Smelter project sought to construct a primary aluminum smelter in Pavlodar with a capacity of 250,000 tons per year (see “Information on Kazakhstan Electrolytic plant JSC”). In addition to financing the smelter, the loan was intended to pay for costs incurred during the first and second phases of the electrolysis plant (see “Overview of key developments from analysts of Asyl Invest JSC (Kazakhstan) on April 16, 2010”). China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was the EPC contractor. Construction began in 2014 (see “President of Kazakhstan Inspects CPC Plant Undertaken by NFC in Pavlodar”). The project was accepted as complete on December 11, 2015 (see "Two Projects Undertaken by NFC Passed Kazakhstan National Unified Acceptance").

The Pavlodar aluminium smelter site was located to the south-east of the Pavlodar residential zone: 13.5 km away from its boundary and 10 km away from the operating alumina refinery and from the heat power plant of the JSC Aluminium of Kazakhstan (see pg.4 of “COMPOSITION OF THE PROJECT.”). More detailed locational information is available at https://www.google.com/maps/search/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80+%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8E%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9/@52.2603189,77.040134,16z and https://www.agaportal.de/_Resources/Persistent/f6d7a1fe4da7c0a59acaafa041c2e96408d4d75f/eia_kasachstan_aluminium.pdf.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=FINAE00020100416e64g0000t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kase.kz/news/show/1099307, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kazcham.com/enrc-subsidiary-secures-400-million-loan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.agaportal.de/_Resources/Persistent/f6d7a1fe4da7c0a59acaafa041c2e96408d4d75f/eia_kasachstan_aluminium.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.nfc.com.cn/templates/t_new_list2/index.aspx?nodeid=82&page=contentpage&contentid=77, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.nfc.com.cn/templates/en_T_new_list2/index.aspx?nodeid=93&page=ContentPage&contentid=3758, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.nfc.com.cn/templates/en_T_new_list2/index.aspx?nodeid=93&page=ContentPage&contentid=3788, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.erg.kz/en/content/deyatel-nost/ao-alyuminiy-kazahstana, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.org.cn/business/2009-10/09/content_18667202.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.nfc.com.cn/templates/en_T_jxcx/index.aspx?nodeid=328, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://old.kdb.kz/upload/iblock/068/KEZ-eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.kdb.kz/en/ajax/project.php?PROJECT_ID=7703&LANG=EN_, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/kda9ef2pfor3ura/Development%20Bank%20of%20Kazakhstan%202010%20Bond%20Prospectus.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/p22jt2pz5fawj2x/2012%20Bond%20Prospectus%20for%20Development%20Bank%20of%20Kazakhstan.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.erg.kz/en/content/deyatel-nost/ao-kazahstanskiy-elektroliznyy-zavod, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

name: Pavlodarskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.

name: Aksuskiy

title: CDB provides $300 million USD via credit line for Third Phase of Sulphide Ore Processing Plant Project at the Aktogay Mine (Linked to Project ID#39557 and #41941)
description:
In 2016, China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $300 million USD loan via credit line to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) for the third phase of the construction of a sulphide ore processing plant at the Aktogay deposit in East Kazakhstan Region (pg.4 of "DBK 2016 Annual Report"). DBK then used these loan proceeds to on-lend to KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP (a project company and special purpose vehicle responsible for the financing, design, and construction of the Sulphide Ore Processing Plant Project at the Aktogay Mine). This loan agreement with AKAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP carried the following terms: a maturity period of 8.5 years and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + 4.50% (see "KAZ Minerals: Credit line approval"). DBK additionally provided $600 million USD for the project, while KAZ Minerals added $963 million USD. The plant was expected to have a capacity of 25 million tons annually (see "Information on KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP"). In 2014, China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was granted the contract to construct the sulphide concentrator (see "Chinese Projects Bring New Opportunities to Aktogay in Kazakhstan"). The main sulphide concentrator was commissioned on December 6, 2016 (see "NEW $300 MILLION CREDIT FACILITY WITH DEVELOPMENT BANK OF KAZAKHSTAN AND PXF UPDATE"). Production began in February 2017 (see "Completion of Koksay Project Investment By NFC").

STAFF_NOTE: Because the exact date of signing of the CDB-DBK deal was unknown, the average 6-month LIBOR for the year 2016 was used instead, 1.058%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 1.058% + 4.5%, or 5.558%. This loan is linked to two previous loans for the Aktogay Mine (Kazakh: Ақтоғай мыс кен орны), a large scale, open pit mine with an average copper grade of 0.36% (oxide) and 0.33% (sulphide). In 2011, CDB committed two loans (see Project ID#41941 and #39557) worth $1.5 billion USD: a $1.34 billion USD and an RMB 1 billion loan to develop the Aktogay mine for copper cathode production.

The Aktogay mine is located in south eastern Kazakhstan in East Kazakhstan Province approximately 250 km from the Kazakhstan-China border.  Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mestorozhdeniye+Aktogay/@46.9524266,79.9318158,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x21c2027241e0b5c9?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiEgqWXqJvpAhUhYTUKHWKYCJQQ_BIwFXoECBQQCg and https://www.mindat.org/maps.php?id=208333.
sources: https://www.kdb.kz/upload/iblock/1c6/BRK_AR_2016_EN_electric.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/english/spc/2017-02/28/content_739337.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.kazminerals.com/repository/news-container/news/2016/new-300-million-credit-facility-with-development-bank-of-kazakhstan-and-pxf-update/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://web.archive.org/web/20181018222611/https://halykfinance.kz/en/site/index/research/news:104355, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.nederlandwereldwijd.nl/binaries/nederlandwereldwijd/documenten/publicaties/2016/08/08/economic-newsletter-on-kazakhstan/newsletterjuly2016.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/2h7ouxynlhyb2wc/cdb%20loan%20to%20kaz%20minerals%20aktogay%20llp.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aktogay_mine, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/news/market-news/market-news-detail/KAZ/14135732.html, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

name: Ayagozskiy

title: China Development Bank provides a $1.34 billion USD loan for the Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project (Linked to Project ID #39557 and #53580)
description:
On June 13, 2011, Kazykhmys PLC (now called KAZ Minerals PLC) signed a memorandum of understanding with China Development Bank (CDB) for a $1.5 billion USD loan to develop its, Aktogay Copper Mine Project (see "中方贷款给哈15亿美元开发铜矿"). On December 16, 2011, CDB signed two bilateral agreements with KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP, a subsidiary of Kazykhmys, to set up loan facilities worth $1.5 billion USD for the mine (pg.105 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). 

Then, on February 16, 2012 the loan was finalized and signed as two tranches, to be available for draw down for three years: one for RMB 1 billion ($158 million USD), the other for $1.34 billion USD (see "Kazakhmys announces $1.5 billion loan facility to fund Aktogay project"). The maturity period was 15 years from the date of first draw down and the grace period is 3 years for both loan tranches. The interest rate for the USD-denominated loan tranche (as captured by this project) is LIBOR + a 4.20% margin and the interest rate for the RMB tranche (captured by linked project ID#39557) was based on the applicable benchmark lending rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). KAZ Minerals PLC provided a guarantee for these loans. As of December 31, 2015, the RMB facility was fully drawn down. To protect against currency risks, KAZ Minerals swapped the interest basis from a RMB interest rate into a USD LIBOR interest basis. As of December 31, 2016, the USD facility was fully drawn down. Arrangement fees with an amortized cost of $15 million, were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39 (see pg.137 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). The USD facility was repayable in half-yearly installments beginning in March 2018 (see pg.45 of "KAZ MINERALS PLC AUDITED RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2017").

 The 2016 audited KAZ Minerals financial report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.12% and 4.33% (as of December 31, 2016) and 5.12% and 3.93% (as December 31, 2015), respectively (see pg.136 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). The 2017 report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.60% and 4.54% (as of December 31, 2017) respectively (see pg.45 of "KAZ MINERALS PLC AUDITED RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2017"). AidData has used this most recent information to code the interest rates of these projects.
The development cost of the copper mine was $2 billion USD, with KAZ Minerals seeking to fund the remaining $500 million USD. The mine was eventually expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually beginning in 2015 (see "中方贷款给哈15亿美元开发铜矿"). The project was comprised of an open-pit mine and an on-site concentrator to produce copper cathode from oxide ore and copper concentrate from the sulphide ore, with molybdenum as a by-product. Alarko was the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor responsible for the processing plant at Aktogay. BIR provided engineering and consultancy services for architectural, civil, mechanical and electrical works for the project. ABB provided complete electrification and automation solutions and three gearless mill drive systems, while Ausenco was contracted to work on the open-pit mine. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was awarded the contract for the construction of the sulphide concentrator. Construction began in 2013 (see "Aktogay Copper Mine"). Copper cathode production from oxide began on December 1, 2015 (see slide 16 of "2015 Full Year Results"). CDB would later commit $300 million USD in 2016 specifically for the construction of the sulphide concentrator by NFC, as captured by linked project ID#53580.

The Aktogay mine is located in southeastern Kazakhstan in East Kazakhstan Region approximately 250 km from the Kazakhstan-China border (see "Aktogay Copper Mine"). Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mestorozhdeniye+Aktogay/@46.9524266,79.9318158,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x21c2027241e0b5c9?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiEgqWXqJvpAhUhYTUKHWKYCJQQ_BIwFXoECBQQCg and https://www.mindat.org/maps.php?id=208333.

title: China Development Bank provides a RMB 1 billion loan for the Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project (Linked to Project ID #41941 and #53580)
description:
On June 13, 2011, Kazykhmys PLC (now called KAZ Minerals PLC) signed a memorandum of understanding with China Development Bank (CDB) for a $1.5 billion USD loan to develop its, Aktogay Copper Mine Project (see "中方贷款给哈15亿美元开发铜矿"). On December 16, 2011, CDB signed two bilateral agreements with KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP, a subsidiary of Kazykhmys, to set up loan facilities worth $1.5 billion USD for the mine (pg.105 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016").

Then, on February 16, 2012 the loan was finalized and signed as two tranches, to be available for draw down for three years: one for RMB 1 billion ($158 million USD), the other for $1.34 billion USD (see "Kazakhmys announces $1.5 billion loan facility to fund Aktogay project"). The maturity period was 15 years from the date of first draw down and the grace period is 3 years for both loan tranches. The interest rate for the USD-denominated loan tranche (captured by linked project ID#41941) is LIBOR + a 4.20% margin and the interest rate for the RMB tranche (captured by this project) was based on the applicable benchmark lending rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). KAZ Minerals PLC provided a guarantee for these loans. As of December 31, 2015, the RMB facility was fully drawn down. To protect against currency risks, KAZ Minerals swapped the interest basis from a RMB interest rate into a USD LIBOR interest basis. As of December 31, 2016, the USD facility was fully drawn down. Arrangement fees with an amortized cost of $15 million, were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39 (see pg.137 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). The USD facility was repayable in half-yearly installments beginning in March 2018 (see pg.45 of "KAZ MINERALS PLC AUDITED RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2017").

 The 2016 audited KAZ Minerals financial report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.12% and 4.33% (as of December 31, 2016) and 5.12% and 3.93% (as December 31, 2015), respectively (see pg.136 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). The 2017 report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.60% and 4.54% (as of December 31, 2017) respectively (see pg.45 of "KAZ MINERALS PLC AUDITED RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2017"). AidData has used this most recent information to code the interest rates of these projects.

The development cost of the copper mine was $2 billion USD, with KAZ Minerals seeking to fund the remaining $500 million USD. The mine was eventually expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually beginning in 2015 (see "中方贷款给哈15亿美元开发铜矿"). The project was comprised of an open-pit mine and an on-site concentrator to produce copper cathode from oxide ore and copper concentrate from the sulphide ore, with molybdenum as a by-product. Alarko was the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor responsible for the processing plant at Aktogay. BIR provided engineering and consultancy services for architectural, civil, mechanical and electrical works for the project. ABB provided complete electrification and automation solutions and three gearless mill drive systems, while Ausenco was contracted to work on the open-pit mine. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was awarded the contract for the construction of the sulphide concentrator. Construction began in 2013 (see "Aktogay Copper Mine"). Copper cathode production from oxide began on December 1, 2015 (see slide 16 of "2015 Full Year Results"). CDB would later commit $300 million USD in 2016 specifically for the construction of the sulphide concentrator by NFC, as captured by linked project ID#53580.

The Aktogay mine is located in southeastern Kazakhstan in East Kazakhstan Region approximately 250 km from the Kazakhstan-China border (see "Aktogay Copper Mine"). Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mestorozhdeniye+Aktogay/@46.9524266,79.9318158,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x21c2027241e0b5c9?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiEgqWXqJvpAhUhYTUKHWKYCJQQ_BIwFXoECBQQCg and https://www.mindat.org/maps.php?id=208333.

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.

title: China Development Bank provides a $200 million USD loan for the 300 MW Moynak Hydropower Plant Construction Project
description:
In June 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $200 million USD export buyer's credit loan agreement with the Moynak Hydroelectric Power Station Joint Stock Company (JSC) for the 300 MW Moynak Hydropower Plant Construction Plant Project (also known as the Moinak Hydro Power Plant or Мойнақ СЭС-і). (see "中哈总理见证公司签约哈萨克斯坦建国以来最大水电站项目"; "Experience"; and "哈萨克斯坦总理签署政府令"). The Government of Kazakhstan established the Moynak Hydro-Electric Power Station JSC in 2005 to own and operate the hydroelectric plant (see "哈萨克斯坦总理签署政府令"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a guarantee for repayment of one half of the amount (see "Kazakhstan’s Electric Power Sector: New Challenges and Opportunities"). The construction of the 300 MW hydroelectric plant had a total cost of $346.6 million USD. In addition to the $200 million CDB loan, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK)  provided loans worth $118.6 million USD, while Moynak Hydro-Electric Power Station JSC contributed $28 million USD (see "Information on Moynak HPP JSC").

Construction on the plant had started in 1985 but then stopped in 1992 due to the collapse of the Soviet Union. Thanks to the CDB financing, construction on the power plant started anew. The Moynak plant was designed to house two 150 MW turbines that could generate 1.27 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity per year. The project sought to end energy shortages in southern Kazakhstan with its reliable energy, enabling growth in the industrial sector of the region (see "Analysis: Kazakhstan's hydroelectric potential attracts foreign investment").

China International Water and Electric Corporation (CWE), China Geo-Engineering Corporation (CGC), and Chengdu Hydropower Investigation and Design Institute (CHIDI) jointly implemented the Moynak Hydropower Plant Construction Project (see "中国公司在哈萨克斯坦承建的水电站引水隧洞贯通"). The project included the design, manufacturing, supply, installation, commissioning, training, and maintenance for the plant, with a quality assurance period for major equipment of 20 years (see "哈萨克斯坦总理签署政府令"). The station was expected to be completed and put into operation in December 2009 (see "公司获准承建哈萨克斯坦第一个自主开发水电站工程"). The launching ceremony of construction was held on August 8, 2008 (see "陆国俊总经理出席玛依纳水电站工程启动仪式"). The Moynak hydropower plant was commissioned on December 9, 2011. In 2012, it generated 503,98 million kWh of electricity (see "History of the company").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of the power station is 联营体承建的哈萨克斯坦玛依纳水电站. Another alternative name in English is “Construction of Moynak HPP on Charyn river.” Moynak is also spelled "Moinak."

The power station was located in the village of Moynak near the town of Kegen, approximately 200 km from Almaty, along the Charyn (also spelled Sharyn) River in Almaty Region. Its exact locational coordinates are 43°03′44″N 78°47′05″E.  More detailed locational information can be found at https://latitude.to/articles-by-country/kz/kazakhstan/296322/moinak-hydro-power-plant
