title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.

name: Sarkandskiy

title: Chinese Government provides $17.2 million USD for the Chukurbulak Dam Construction Project on the Khorgos River
description:
On June 8, 2017, during the visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping to Kazakhstan, the Chinese Government and the Government of Kazakhstan signed an agreement on the construction of the Chukurbulak («Шұқырбұлақ») dam on the Khorgos River (see "Negotiations with Xi JInping, Chairman of the People's Republic of China, in expanded format"). The estimated cost of the project was $34.4 million USD (₸11.7 billion KZT) (see "Kazakhstan, China to construct dam on Khorgos River"). The Chinese Government provided 50% of the financing for the project, or $17.2 million USD, while the Government of Kazakhstan provided the other 50% (see "Kazakhstan, China to construct dam on Khorgos River"). China was set to own 50% of the dam after completion, while the other half would be property of Kazakhstan (see "Kazakhstan, China to jointly build dam on Khorgos river"). The Parliament of Kazakhstan ratified the agreement on June 21, 2018 (see "Kazakhstan's Parliament ratifies agreement with China on construction of dike").

The mudflow dam was located on Khorgos River 5 kilometers upstream from the Kazakh-Chinese joint Dostyk Hydraulic Power System, in the small town of Dostyk in the Almaty Region on the border with China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. The dam was intended to protect the Khorgos International Center for Cross-Border Cooperation, the Dostyk Hydraulic Power System, the Baskunchi and Khorgos settlements, the Atasu-Alashankou oil pipeline, road and railway bridges, and the people living in the river's lower basin, from mudflows and floods. The Committee for Emergency Situations of Kazakh Ministry of Internal Affairs and Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps were responsible for the dam. Experts from both countries performed cost estimates and created designs for the project. A Kazakh-China committee was to be established to manage the construction process, while the operation and management was to be determined by a later agreement (see "Kazakhstan, China to construct dam on Khorgos River").

The construction of the dam included a central reinforced concrete section (featuring the necessary metal structures), an earth part of the dam, a control and measuring system, and a temporary cofferdam and drainage channel for passing water during the construction period, as well as 200-meter shore protection structures (dams) under the dam (see "Kazakhstan and China to construct dam on Khorgos River"). The dam was designed to intercept mudflows of up to 9.8 million cubic meters (see "Kazakh-Chinese dam to protect ICBC Khorgos"). Part of the dam was located on Chinese territory (see "ПОЗДРАВЛЯЕМ!"). Construction began on April 18, 2019 (see "АЛМАТЫ ОБЛЫСЫНЫҢ ҚОРҒАС ӨЗЕНІНДЕ «ШҰҚЫРБҰЛАҚ»...").

STAFF_NOTE: The Kazakh name of this project is «Шұқырбұлақ» (Алмалы) бірлескен қазақстан-қытай сел ұстайтын бөгетінің құрылысын. No source states that China gave $17.2 million USD; AidData took this number by dividing the estimated project cost of $34.4 million USD in half.  "Flow type" is likely a grant, but no source has corroborated that; therefore, it was coded as "Vague TBD."
sources: http://kz2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/chinanews/201805/20180502750223.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://bnews.kz/en/news/kazakhstan_and_china_to_construct_dam_on_khorgos_river, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://lenta.inform.kz/en/kazakh-chinese-dam-to-protect-icbc-khorgos_a3035179, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://en.trend.az/business/economy/2919711.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.akorda.kz/en/events/akorda_news/meetings_and_receptions/negotiations-with-xi-jinping-chairman-of-the-peoples-republic-of-china-in-expanded-format, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://astanatimes.com/2018/07/kazakhstan-china-to-construct-dam-on-khorgos-river/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://mail.icwc-aral.littel.uz/yearbook/pdf/05_yearbook2018_en.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20190422101106/http://emer.gov.kz/kz/59194-almaty-oblysyny-or-as-zeninde-sh-yrb-la-birlesken-aza-stan-ytaj-sel-stajtyn-b-getini-rylysyn-bastau-r-simi-tti, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://kaztag.info/en/news/kazakhstan-s-parliament-ratifies-agreement-with-china-on-construction-of-dike, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.kt.kz/eng/society/kazakhstan_and_china_to_construct_dam_on_khorgos_river_1153657495.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.facebook.com/426974090985290/posts/1281337158882308/, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs
GEO_notes: The maps and other location details make it appear that the Dam is located in Alakolskiy District. While it is called Chukurbulak Dam, the city appears to nowhere near the river while other sources name it upstream of Dostyk Hydraulic Power System.
name: Alakolskiy

name: Alakolskiy

title: ICBC provides $300 million USD to refinance notes issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #72865)
description:
JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

To finance the 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, CNODC and KTO contributed $50 million USD of their own funds (as captured by linked project ID#39605; in addition, $600 million USD was raised through the issuing of Eurobonds by JP Morgan Bank (see "Atasu-Alashankou project"). Then, in August 2013, KCP entered into a $300 million facility agreement with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Almaty) JSC (ICBC Almaty) to refinance notes that it had issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project. This loan facility bears interest at a rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 3.75% margin per annum. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $180 million USD (₸59.8 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on this information, interest rate was recorded as 6-month LIBOR in August 2013 (0.395%) + 3.75%, or 4.145%; the maturity and grace periods are unknown.

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The original financing of the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605.

The 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline runs from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China. It passes through the Karaganda, East-Kazakhstan and Almaty regions of Kazakhstan. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/.
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/uploads/user_31/2019_30_07__01_08_01__775.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/history?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/atasu_alashankou, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Zhanaarkinskiy, Shetskiy, Aktogayskiy, and Alakolskiy Districts are all coded for this project since the pipeline that was funded for construction runs through all these districts. The location of the pipeline is found on slide 4 of the powerpoint provided in the project description. (Alakolskiy)
name: Alakolskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $434.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54991, and #55016)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $434.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see signing date at "KazAvtoZhol Company signed a bilateral agreement..."). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства...").

The total cost of this project was $511 million USD; co-financiers are unknown. China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Work on the 415 km road from Kalbatau to Maykapshagai began in May 2019 and was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造. Another Chinese name is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路. The project is sometimes known as the "KM415 Project" in English.
sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20180611124851/https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/kompaniya-kazavtozhol-podpisala-dvustoronnee-soglashenie-v-ramkakh-foruma-odin-poyas-odin-put, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xxg.com.cn/s/2751-6844-30683.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/predsedatel-ao-nk-azavtozhol-proveril-khod-rabot-ob-ektov-rekonstruktsii-v-vostochno-kazakhstanskoj-oblasti, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xxg.com.cn/s/1312-4622-24.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/5d5y0hhe1xy9wuu/KazAvtoZhol_2018_FS_ENG.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://zakon.uchet.kz/rus/docs/P1800000047, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazautozhol.kz/oldweb/images/Investors/KazAvtoZhol_2018_FS_ENG.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://adilet.zan.kz/kaz/docs/P1300001409, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://adilet.zan.kz/kaz/docs/P1300001409, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/article/i/jyjl/e/201905/20190502867981.shtml , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/xgv3iw1vdrwkq40/KazAvtoZhol%20Company%20signed%20a%20bilateral%20agreement%20within%20the%20framework%20of%20the%20Forum%20_One%20Belt%2C%20One%20Way__.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.buildhr.com/company/SeLBU/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
GEO_notes: Zharminskiy, Kokpektinskiy, Tarbagatayskiy, and Zaysanskiy Districts are all coded for this project since the road that received funding for reconstruction runs through all of these districts. The location of the Kalbatau-Maykapshagai portion of the road was found on the 41st page of the pdf (pg 25 on the document), but note that there is a different spelling for Maykapshagai where in the document the spelling for the location is Maykapchagay. (Zharminskiy)
name: Zharminskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.

name: Urdzharskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.

title: China Eximbank provides a $434.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54991, and #55016)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $434.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see signing date at "KazAvtoZhol Company signed a bilateral agreement..."). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства...").

The total cost of this project was $511 million USD; co-financiers are unknown. China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Work on the 415 km road from Kalbatau to Maykapshagai began in May 2019 and was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造. Another Chinese name is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路. The project is sometimes known as the "KM415 Project" in English.
sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20180611124851/https://primeminister.kz/en/news/all/gosprogramma-nurli-zhol-avtomobilnie-dorogi-logistika-zhkh-16616, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/kompaniya-kazavtozhol-podpisala-dvustoronnee-soglashenie-v-ramkakh-foruma-odin-poyas-odin-put, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xxg.com.cn/s/2751-6844-30683.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kazautozhol.kz/index.php/ru/pressa/novosti/item/predsedatel-ao-nk-azavtozhol-proveril-khod-rabot-ob-ektov-rekonstruktsii-v-vostochno-kazakhstanskoj-oblasti, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xxg.com.cn/s/1312-4622-24.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/5d5y0hhe1xy9wuu/KazAvtoZhol_2018_FS_ENG.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://zakon.uchet.kz/rus/docs/P1800000047, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kazautozhol.kz/oldweb/images/Investors/KazAvtoZhol_2018_FS_ENG.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://adilet.zan.kz/kaz/docs/P1300001409, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://adilet.zan.kz/kaz/docs/P1300001409, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/article/i/jyjl/e/201905/20190502867981.shtml , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.genertec.com.cn/s/8293-22545-102110.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/xgv3iw1vdrwkq40/KazAvtoZhol%20Company%20signed%20a%20bilateral%20agreement%20within%20the%20framework%20of%20the%20Forum%20_One%20Belt%2C%20One%20Way__.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.buildhr.com/company/SeLBU/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
GEO_notes: Zharminskiy, Kokpektinskiy, Tarbagatayskiy, and Zaysanskiy Districts are all coded for this project since the road that received funding for reconstruction runs through all of these districts. The location of the Kalbatau-Maykapshagai portion of the road was found on the 41st page of the pdf (pg 25 on the document), but note that there is a different spelling for Maykapshagai where in the document the spelling for the location is Maykapchagay. (Tarbagatayskiy)

This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства...").

The total cost of this project was $511 million USD; co-financiers are unknown. China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Work on the 415 km road from Kalbatau to Maykapshagai began in May 2019 and was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造. Another Chinese name is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路. The project is sometimes known as the "KM415 Project" in English.

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

title: CDB provides $350 million USD via a $700 million USD syndicated loan for Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Additional Financing) (Linked to Project ID#39562 and #73384)

title: China National Petroleum Corporation funds the repair and maintenance of kindergartens in the Mangystau Region
description:
In 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) funded the repair and maintenance of community kindergartens in the Mangystau Region (see "CNPC in Kazakhstan").

STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as "Completion" because it is evident that the funds were completely disbursed. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2010. Some sources ("Китайская Национальная Нефтегазовая корпорация (CNPC) - это") claim that JSC MangistauMunaigas, a 50/50 joint venture between CNPC and KazMunayGas, funded this, while others say CNPC. AidData has chosen CNPC as the funder for the time being, because it was involved either way.
sources: https://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/cnpc/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/ru/sqjs/hjysh_common.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://economic-definition.com/Companies_of_China/Kitayskaya_Nacional_naya_Neftegazovaya_korporaciya_CNPC__eto.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
GEO_notes: The CNPC website says they fund kindergartens in Mangystau but no additional location information was found.
name: Mangghystau

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

GEO_notes: Coded up to ADM1 to the Aktyubinsk/Aktobe region. The description said the pipeline ran through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions which i geocoded using qgis and geojson
name: Aqtöbe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas donates sports equipment to the children of the Aktobe Seagull Children Recovery Center
description: On International Children's Day, June 1, 2006, at the Aktobe Seagull Children Recovery Center, employees of CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, presented gifts to the children at the center. The children suffered from chronic diseases and were at the center for long-time isolated treatment. The gifts provided to them included soccer balls, basketballs, and badminton rackets (see pg.41 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008'). STAFF_NOTE: While there are several children's rehabilitation centers in the Aktobe Region, there does not appear to be one that goes by the name Aktobe Seagull Children Recovery Center, which may be due to translation issues. AidData has chosen the Aktobe regional government as the recipient in light of this.
sources: http://csr.cnpc.com.cn/cnpccsr/xhtml/PageAssets/CNPCinKazakhstan2008en.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Coded up to ADM1 to the Aktobe Region. The location of the school couldnt be found, so coded up the region as did AidData. The location details and description gave aktobe region as the location
name: Aqtöbe

title: ICBC participates in a $1.18 billion USD loan facility for the 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol Section of the Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #54523)
description:
On August 12, 2008, Chinese-Kazakh joint venture Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP entered into a $1.18 billion USD credit facility with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and the ING Bank N.V. for a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing the construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches. It drew down three in 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of $1 billion USD. The availability period of this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. The borrowed funds bore an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2% margin per annum until February 2013 and 6-month LIBOR + a 4% margin per annum thereafter. CNPC provided a guarantee from the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was $403.9 million USD (including the capitalised interest) (₸134.3 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on the information above, the interest rate was recorded as 6-Month LIBOR in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, or 5.108%, while the maturity period is 10 years and the grace period is zero. 

JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). 

This project sought to the construct the Kenkiyak–Kumkol pipeline, which was intended to transport oil from West Kazakhstan and Aktobe oilfields. It began in Kenkiyak and ended in Kumkol. The pipeline was 794.263 km long and it had a maximum capacity of10 million tons a year. It included relay pump stations to increase the volume of oil transported (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline About"). The pipe had diameters ranging between 0.5 and 1.8 meters (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline passed through the Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda regions, with its oil destined for the Chinese market. JSC OGCC KazStroyService was responsible for the construction of the 483 km section from Kenkiyak to Aralsk, while China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co., Ltd. (CPPE) was responsible for the construction of a 311 km section to Kumkol. Construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline began on December 11, 2007 (see "Kenkiyak - Kumkol"). The pipeline went into operation on October 6, 2009 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline").

As of 31 December 31, 2017, the pipeline had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In 2017, 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil were transported through the pipeline. Pursuant to an agreement between the KTO and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was increased from 10.0 million tonnes of crude oil per year to 20.0 million tonnes in
2015 so as to take advantage of expected increased production at Tengiz Field and Kashagan Field. Ten companies supply oil to the pipeline, which KCP has continued to own (pg.158 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605, while the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline is captured by linked project ID#54523.

STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier (ING Bank N.V.) and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. This project is sometimes called “Second stage of Kazakhstan-China oil pipeline construction."

The 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline runs from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan and runs through three regions (Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda). A 483 km segment runs from the Kenkiyak station to the Aralsk area, and a 311 km segment to the Kumkol station. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/project1?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/about?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazakhstan%E2%80%93China_oil_pipeline, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.reuters.com/article/kazakhstan-china-pipeline/kazakhstan-expands-china-oil-pipeline-link-idUSL17937520090701, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.linklaters.com/en-us/find-a-lawyer/xiaohui-ji, Other; http://www.kcp.kz/company/history?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/centralasia/pipeline.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://kaztransoil.kz/en/about/history/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.painestevens.com/about-us/lawyer-biographies/benjamin-paine.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Aktobe Region is coded in this row because it contains the endpoint and parts of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. I could not find a map with the ADM2s of the pipeline so I coded up to the ADM1s listed in the source.
name: Aqtöbe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas donates computers to seconday schools in the Aktobe Region
description:
Before 2007, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, signed a memorandum of mutual cooperation with the Akimat of Aktobe region to donate personal computers to secondary schools in the Aktobe Region (see "Внешняя благотворительность"). CNPC AMG annually provided the computers to the schools (see "Стратегия компании: мировые стандарты и благотворительность"). As of May 2007, CNPC AMG had donated 400 computers (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г."). The amount of donated computers later increased to 500 (see "Внешняя благотворительность").

STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear what year the memorandum was signed in; it was after 2000, the year when CNPC began signing memorandums with the Aktobe Akimat (see "Внешняя благотворительность"), and before 2007, because 400 computers had been donated by then (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г.").
sources: http://www.cnpc-amg.kz/?p=vnesh_blag, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.panoramakz.com/index.php/archive?y=2007&n=16, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://online.zakon.kz/Document/?doc_id=30163802#pos=3;-52, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded up to ADM1 for the Akotbe region since the donated computers were going to the Akotbe region with no specific district mentioned. Furthermore, the description and location details both have the Aktobe region as the location
name: Aqtöbe

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

title: CDB provides $350 million USD via a $700 million USD syndicated loan for Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Additional Financing) (Linked to Project ID#39562 and #73384)
description:

The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (see linked project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). This project captures the CDB contribution; for the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

title: ICBC participates in a $1.18 billion USD loan facility for the 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol Section of the Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #54523)
description:
On August 12, 2008, Chinese-Kazakh joint venture Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP entered into a $1.18 billion USD credit facility with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and the ING Bank N.V. for a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing the construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches. It drew down three in 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of $1 billion USD. The availability period of this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. The borrowed funds bore an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2% margin per annum until February 2013 and 6-month LIBOR + a 4% margin per annum thereafter. CNPC provided a guarantee from the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was $403.9 million USD (including the capitalised interest) (₸134.3 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on the information above, the interest rate was recorded as 6-Month LIBOR in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, or 5.108%, while the maturity period is 10 years and the grace period is zero. 

JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). 

This project sought to the construct the Kenkiyak–Kumkol pipeline, which was intended to transport oil from West Kazakhstan and Aktobe oilfields. It began in Kenkiyak and ended in Kumkol. The pipeline was 794.263 km long and it had a maximum capacity of10 million tons a year. It included relay pump stations to increase the volume of oil transported (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline About"). The pipe had diameters ranging between 0.5 and 1.8 meters (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline passed through the Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda regions, with its oil destined for the Chinese market. JSC OGCC KazStroyService was responsible for the construction of the 483 km section from Kenkiyak to Aralsk, while China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co., Ltd. (CPPE) was responsible for the construction of a 311 km section to Kumkol. Construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline began on December 11, 2007 (see "Kenkiyak - Kumkol"). The pipeline went into operation on October 6, 2009 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline").

As of 31 December 31, 2017, the pipeline had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In 2017, 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil were transported through the pipeline. Pursuant to an agreement between the KTO and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was increased from 10.0 million tonnes of crude oil per year to 20.0 million tonnes in
2015 so as to take advantage of expected increased production at Tengiz Field and Kashagan Field. Ten companies supply oil to the pipeline, which KCP has continued to own (pg.158 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605, while the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline is captured by linked project ID#54523.

STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier (ING Bank N.V.) and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. This project is sometimes called “Second stage of Kazakhstan-China oil pipeline construction."

The 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline runs from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan and runs through three regions (Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda). A 483 km segment runs from the Kenkiyak station to the Aralsk area, and a 311 km segment to the Kumkol station. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
