name: Qyzylorda

title: China National Petroleum Corporation donates $4 million USD to the Kyzylorda Region (Linked to Project ID#73456)
description: In 2007, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) donated $4 million USD to the Kyzylorda Region. This donation, alongside a $1.8 million USD donation to the South Kazakhstan Region (as captured by linked project ID#73456), funded the construction of a railway, a community park, a school and library, and improvements to drinking water and power supply (see 'CNPC in Kazakhstan'). STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as 'Completion' because it is evident that the funds were completely disbursed. 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2007.
sources: https://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/cnpc/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/ru/sqjs/hjysh_common.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan for the Kazakhstani Section of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (Linked to Project ID#40833, #39955, #54489, #54528, and #70616)
description:
The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, also known as the China-Central Asia Gas Pipeline or, simply, the Asia Gas Pipeline, is a 1,873-km long gas pipeline connecting Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, delivering gas equal to approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption. It consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D). A, B, and C run parallel to each other. The pipelines begin at Gedaim on the Turkmen-Uzbek border, run through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and end at Khorgas in China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Line A (#40833 and #54489) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines — Line B (ID#40834 and #54489) and Line C (ID#39997) — started their operations in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (ID#39955 and #70616), which is under construction, will run through Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Kyrgyzstan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C provide 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介").

JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) with China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline in Kazakhstan. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each held a 50% equity stake in AGP (see pg.37 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus”).
 
This project records the financing of the Kazakhstani segment of Line C, which is sometimes referred to as a part of the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. The financing of the Uzbek section is captured by linked project ID#54528. The 1,830 km long pipeline begins at the Turkmen-Uzbek border and ends at Khorgas in Xinjiang. Construction of Line C began in September 2012. The overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Line C went into operation on May 31, 2014 (see "Flow of natural gas from Central Asia"). It began transferring gas to China in June 2014 (see "Gas trade for the better"). Line C successfully transmitted gas to Khorgas on June 15, 2017 (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介"). Line C has a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, and its pipe diameter is 1,219 mm, 152 mm larger than Line A/B. Upon completion of all supporting facilities of Line C, the overall delivery capacity of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline was expected to reach 55 billion cubic meters per annum, equaling approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption while annually substituting 73 million tons of coal and cutting carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide emissions by 78 million tons and 1.21 million tons respectively. Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan contribute each 10 bcm of gas to Line C, while Kazakhstan supplies 5 bcm of gas (see "Flow of natural gas from Central Asia"). 

In December 2012, AGP entered into a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) to finance the construction of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline. The loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.35% margin per annum during the guarantee period and 3-month LIBOR + a 3.45% per annum thereafter. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in June 2017 until December 27, 2027. The loan was secured by a "ship or pay" transportation agreement pledge, account charges, insurance and reinsurance policies assignments, and a guarantee from CNPC. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount from this loan was $2.9 billion USD (see pg.110 and 151 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus” and pg.85 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus”). Based on this information, the interest rate was recorded as 3-Month LIBOR in December 2012 (0.309%) + 2.35%, or 2.659%, while the grace period was 4.5 years, the repayment period was 10.5 years, and the maturity period was 15 years.

title: China Eximbank provides a $43.668 million USD loan to BTA Bank for the construction of South Kazakhstan cement plant
description:
On October 31, 2008, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $43.680 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with BTA Bank (Turan-Alem Bank) to finance construction of a cement plant in the South Kazakhstan Region (see "BTA Bank (Kazakhstan) and Export-Import bank of China sign credit agreement..."). The loan carried a maturity period of six years and a "substantial grace period." It covered 80% of the cost of the project; the remainder was co-financed (see "Cement project strengthens trade co-operation"). BTA Bank then used the proceeds of the PBC loan to on-lend to Standard Cement LLP, the company responsible for the cement plant (see "BTA Bank (Kazakhstan) and Export-Import bank of China sign credit agreement...").

The plant was to have a production capacity of the plant of 1 million tons of Portland cement per year. It was expected to meet the needs of southern Kazakhstan and export to other Central Asia countries (see "Cement project strengthens trade co-operation"). The plant used dry process to create cement, an environmentally-friendly process (see "Standard Cement Company history"). The project included the construction of a cement production line with a daily capacity of 2,500 tons. Tianjin Cement Industry Design & Research Institute Co., Ltd. — a unit of Sinoma International Engineering Co., Ltd. — won the contract from Standard Cement for the design and equipment for the cement production line (see "China’s Sinoma unit wins US$55m Kazakhstan cement plant contract"). The project commenced on May 8, 2012. The project was handed over to Standard Cement on June 25, 2013. After the expiration of the defects notification period, all construction on the project was complete on August 25, 2014 (see "FAC for Kazakhstan Slag Grinding Project of Standard Cement").
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZAEN0020110925e4b30094f&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://kase.kz/en/news/show/1059594/, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20150419221133/http://www.sinoma.com.cn/en/xinwenzixun/qiyedongtai/20140917/59448.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cemnet.com/News/story/153181/bta-bank-to-finance-standard-cement-new-line.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://standard-cement.com/en/istoriya, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/1m80lqtkxyl6sxx/BTA%20Bank%20-%20News.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/jjocutpre4f64dw/Best%20Deals%20of%202008_%20Standard%20Cement%2C%20Kazakhstan%20_%201Global%20Trade%20Review%20%28GTR%29.pdf?dl=0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/z6yyxsdtjef4ya4/BTA%20Bank%20%28Kazakhstan%29%20and%20Export-Import%20bank%20of%20China%20sign%20credit%20agreement%20of%20financing%20of%20construction%20of%20cement%20plant%20in%20South%20Kazakhstan%20-%20Kazakhstan%20Stock%20Exchange%20%28KASE%29.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.cemnet.com/News/story/138713/china-s-sinoma-unit-wins-us-55m-kazakhstan-cement-plant-contract.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.cemnet.com/News/story/138713/china-s-sinoma-unit-wins-us-55m-kazakhstan-cement-plant-contract.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: CDB provides $350 million USD via a $700 million USD syndicated loan for Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Additional Financing) (Linked to Project ID#39562 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (see linked project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). This project captures the CDB contribution; for the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

title: China National Petroleum Corporation donates $1.8 million USD to the South Kazakhstan Region (Linked to Project ID#73455)
description: In 2007, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) donated $1.8 million USD to the South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkestan Region). This donation, alongside a $4 million USD donation to the Kyzylorda Region (as captured by linked project ID#73455), funded the construction of a railway, a community park, a school and library, and improvements to drinking water and power supply (see 'CNPC in Kazakhstan'). STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as 'Completion' because it is evident that the funds were completely disbursed. 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2007.

title: China donates 1million yuan worth equipment to Kazakh police
description: On February 19, 2003 China's Public Security Ministry donated police equipment to the Kazakh Interior Ministry in Almaty. The total cost was 1mil yuan. The police equipment and technology supplied by China includes night vision devices, metal detectors, microscopes, tape recorders, computers, scanners, printers, photo equipment, telephones and flashlights. The agreement on the supply of special equipment by the Chinese Public Security Ministry as technical no-strings aid to the Kazakh Interior Ministry was signed by the sides in Beijing on November 18, 2002.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcca00020030220dz2j00014&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://books.google.com/books?id=AOjIWDJaYQ0C&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20&dq=china+donates+equipment+kazakhstan+police&source=bl&ots=fHWLVMgYkj&sig=nv-SySz01gJNKqbp7L6YA0w7lAU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwii0Myj4-fKAhVKND4KHb6xDrsQ6AEIJzAC#v=onepage&q=china%20donates%20equipment%20kazakhstan%20police&f=false, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://china.org.cn/english/2003/Jun/65983.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

name: North Kazakhstan

title: ICBC participates in a $1.18 billion USD loan facility for the 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol Section of the Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #54523)
description:
On August 12, 2008, Chinese-Kazakh joint venture Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP entered into a $1.18 billion USD credit facility with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and the ING Bank N.V. for a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing the construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches. It drew down three in 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of $1 billion USD. The availability period of this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. The borrowed funds bore an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2% margin per annum until February 2013 and 6-month LIBOR + a 4% margin per annum thereafter. CNPC provided a guarantee from the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was $403.9 million USD (including the capitalised interest) (₸134.3 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on the information above, the interest rate was recorded as 6-Month LIBOR in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, or 5.108%, while the maturity period is 10 years and the grace period is zero. 

JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). 

This project sought to the construct the Kenkiyak–Kumkol pipeline, which was intended to transport oil from West Kazakhstan and Aktobe oilfields. It began in Kenkiyak and ended in Kumkol. The pipeline was 794.263 km long and it had a maximum capacity of10 million tons a year. It included relay pump stations to increase the volume of oil transported (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline About"). The pipe had diameters ranging between 0.5 and 1.8 meters (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline passed through the Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda regions, with its oil destined for the Chinese market. JSC OGCC KazStroyService was responsible for the construction of the 483 km section from Kenkiyak to Aralsk, while China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co., Ltd. (CPPE) was responsible for the construction of a 311 km section to Kumkol. Construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline began on December 11, 2007 (see "Kenkiyak - Kumkol"). The pipeline went into operation on October 6, 2009 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline").

As of 31 December 31, 2017, the pipeline had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In 2017, 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil were transported through the pipeline. Pursuant to an agreement between the KTO and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was increased from 10.0 million tonnes of crude oil per year to 20.0 million tonnes in
2015 so as to take advantage of expected increased production at Tengiz Field and Kashagan Field. Ten companies supply oil to the pipeline, which KCP has continued to own (pg.158 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605, while the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline is captured by linked project ID#54523.

STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier (ING Bank N.V.) and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. This project is sometimes called “Second stage of Kazakhstan-China oil pipeline construction."

The 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline runs from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan and runs through three regions (Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda). A 483 km segment runs from the Kenkiyak station to the Aralsk area, and a 311 km segment to the Kumkol station. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
sources: http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/projects/project1?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.kcp.kz/company/about?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kazakhstan%E2%80%93China_oil_pipeline, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.reuters.com/article/kazakhstan-china-pipeline/kazakhstan-expands-china-oil-pipeline-link-idUSL17937520090701, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.linklaters.com/en-us/find-a-lawyer/xiaohui-ji, Other; http://www.kcp.kz/company/history?language=en, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/centralasia/pipeline.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://kaztransoil.kz/en/about/history/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.painestevens.com/about-us/lawyer-biographies/benjamin-paine.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Karaganda Region is coded in this row because it contains the endpoint and parts of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. I could not find a map with the ADM2s of the pipeline so I coded up to the ADM1s listed in the source.
name: Qaraghandy

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan for the Kazakhstani Section of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (Linked to Project ID#40833, #39955, #54489, #54528, and #70616)
description:
The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, also known as the China-Central Asia Gas Pipeline or, simply, the Asia Gas Pipeline, is a 1,873-km long gas pipeline connecting Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, delivering gas equal to approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption. It consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D). A, B, and C run parallel to each other. The pipelines begin at Gedaim on the Turkmen-Uzbek border, run through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and end at Khorgas in China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Line A (#40833 and #54489) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines — Line B (ID#40834 and #54489) and Line C (ID#39997) — started their operations in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (ID#39955 and #70616), which is under construction, will run through Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Kyrgyzstan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C provide 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介").

JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) with China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline in Kazakhstan. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each held a 50% equity stake in AGP (see pg.37 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus”).
 
This project records the financing of the Kazakhstani segment of Line C, which is sometimes referred to as a part of the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. The financing of the Uzbek section is captured by linked project ID#54528. The 1,830 km long pipeline begins at the Turkmen-Uzbek border and ends at Khorgas in Xinjiang. Construction of Line C began in September 2012. The overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Line C went into operation on May 31, 2014 (see "Flow of natural gas from Central Asia"). It began transferring gas to China in June 2014 (see "Gas trade for the better"). Line C successfully transmitted gas to Khorgas on June 15, 2017 (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介"). Line C has a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, and its pipe diameter is 1,219 mm, 152 mm larger than Line A/B. Upon completion of all supporting facilities of Line C, the overall delivery capacity of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline was expected to reach 55 billion cubic meters per annum, equaling approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption while annually substituting 73 million tons of coal and cutting carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide emissions by 78 million tons and 1.21 million tons respectively. Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan contribute each 10 bcm of gas to Line C, while Kazakhstan supplies 5 bcm of gas (see "Flow of natural gas from Central Asia"). 

In December 2012, AGP entered into a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) to finance the construction of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline. The loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.35% margin per annum during the guarantee period and 3-month LIBOR + a 3.45% per annum thereafter. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in June 2017 until December 27, 2027. The loan was secured by a "ship or pay" transportation agreement pledge, account charges, insurance and reinsurance policies assignments, and a guarantee from CNPC. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount from this loan was $2.9 billion USD (see pg.110 and 151 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus” and pg.85 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus”). Based on this information, the interest rate was recorded as 3-Month LIBOR in December 2012 (0.309%) + 2.35%, or 2.659%, while the grace period was 4.5 years, the repayment period was 10.5 years, and the maturity period was 15 years.

title: China grants 396,000 USD in equipment for Kazakh Police
description: In 2007 the Chinese Ministry of Public Security provided aid worth 396,000 dollars to the Kazakh Ministry of Internal Affairs. The donation included equipment for Kazakh police.

name: Almaty

title: Chinese Government provides a grant for 1 MW solar power plant and 5 MW wind farm
description:
In December 2009, the Chinese Government pledged that it would provide Kazakhstan with equipment for sample solar batteries and wind turbines (see "Kazakhstan, China deepen energy cooperation"). On September 26, 2011, the Chinese Government signed an agreement on free technical assistance with the Government of Kazakhstan. China agreed to provide a grant of pilot samples of solar batteries and wind turbines to Kazakhstan for renewable energy projects (see "China to give away pilot samples of solar batteries and wind turbines to Kazakhstan"). The equipment from the grant was to enable the construction of a 1 MW solar power plant (SES) and a 5 MW wind farm (WES) (see "China Helps Kazakhstan Build Solar and Wind Power Plants").

The 5 MW wind farm consisted of two wind power plants with a capacity of 2.5 MW each, with project electricity generation of 17 million kWh per year. The construction period was from March to November 2018 (see "China Helps Kazakhstan Build Solar and Wind Power Plants"). The wind farms had 80-meter tall towers and a 53.8-meter long blades that could generate electricity at wind speeds of 3 m/s to 25 m/s. The 5MW wind power plant was to be built in the Yenbekshikazakhsky District of the Almaty Region over an area of 25 ha (see "China to give away pilot samples of solar batteries and wind turbines to Kazakhstan").

The 1 MW solar power station, located in the special economic zone “Park of Innovative Technologies” (or “IT Park”) in the Almaty Region, produced electricity by poly- and single-crystal photoelectric modules, with a projected electricity generation of 1.4 million kW/h per year. The construction period was from December 2017 to October 2018 (see "China Helps Kazakhstan Build Solar and Wind Power Plants"). The solar plant featured 1,716 monocrystalline panels with a capacity of 285 W and 1,892 polycrystalline panels. The power generated from these plants was sold in the network of JSC “Almaty Power Plants” (see "Solar and wind power plants were commissioned in Almaty and Almaty region").

According to the agreement, the Chinese side was to deliver, assemble, and commission the equipment at its own expense, while Kazakhstan was to exempt the equipment from customs duties and taxes (see "China to give away pilot samples of solar batteries and wind turbines to Kazakhstan"). The general contractor for the projects was CITIC Construction Group, and the operators of the wind and solar plants were “Samruk-Energy” JSC and Powerchina Zhongnan Engineering Corp. Ltd. The two 2.5 MW wind farms were produced by the Chinese company Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology Co., Ltd. (see "Solar and wind power plants were commissioned in Almaty and Almaty region"). “Samruk-Green Energy” LLP supervised the construction of projects in order to ensure timely fulfillment of obligations under the agreement (see "Solar and wind power plants were commissioned in Almaty and Almaty region"). The handover ceremony of the solar and wind power stations was held on November 30, 2018 (see "中國援建哈薩克斯坦太陽能及風能電站完成交接").
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KAZWIR0020110927e79q0012x&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.inform.kz/eng/article/2217838, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cntimes.info/docDetail.jsp?coluid=266&docid=104730536, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.people.cn/n3/2019/0426/c90000-9572701.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.world-energy.org/article/4345.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://samruk-green.kz/en/press-center/news/860-20181130-205757, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.evwind.es/2019/11/29/china-helps-kazakhstan-build-solar-and-wind-power-plants/72136, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded the Almaty Region. The location details gave Almaty as the lcoation and the global factiva source states "project will be carried out in the Almaty Region"
name: Almaty

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan for the Kazakhstani Section of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (Linked to Project ID#40833, #39955, #54489, #54528, and #70616)

title: CDB provides a $500 million USD credit line to Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC for industrial development
description: On May 19, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $500 million USD general facility agreement with the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK). The credit line was intended to finance joint projects in non-resource sectors of the Kazakh economy (see signing date at "两家中国银行向哈萨克斯坦开发银行提供15亿美元贷款"; see credit line at "Shanghai Summit Marks Deepening..."; see rest at pg.54 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Annual Report 2014").

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $63,700 USD for newspaper and magazine subscriptions for World War II veterans (Linked to Project ID#73474)
description: On May 9, 2003, Victory Day, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, set aside $63,700 USD to subscribe Kazakhstani veterans of World War II to newspapers and magazines (see pg.41 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008' and 'Seven Years of Honest Co-Operation'). CNPC AMG was still spending that amount every year as of 2017 (see 'Oiling the wheels of cooperation'). This project captures CNPC's purchase of subscriptions in 2005. title: CDB signs $650 million loan agreement with Kazakhstan Development Bank (year 2017) - drawn down amount (linked to project #53575)
description: In March 2017, China Development Bank provided a $650 million loan to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan, for joint Kazakh-Chinese projects in the transportation, infrastructure, and communication sectors. China and Kazakhstan agreed on the line of credit in 2015 and the facility agreement was amended in July 2016. As at 30 June 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the agreement was $170 million. The loan matures in June 2025 and has an interest rate of 2.7% per annum plus LIBOR. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in March 2017 is used in the calculation of interest rate - 1.426% + 2.7% = 4.126% This project captures the drawn down amount of 480 million USD. The full amount is captured in umbrella project #53575. STAFF_NOTE: Not a duplicate of 53574 - 53574 was signed in March 2015 for the same amount. This project was signed in 2017.
sources: https://old.nationalbank.kz/cont/BoP_2016_eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.kdb.kz/upload/iblock/71d/AR2017_KDB_eng_site.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since there is no specific location that received money from the loan and multiple areas are meant to benefit from the loan.
name: Kazakhstan

title: China launches Quick Chinese service in Kazakhstan
description: In August 2016, the Chinese embassy and the Kazakhstan Diplomatic Service jointly launched 'Quick Chinese', a service meant to help Kazakhs learn Chinese, and promote academic exchanges between Chinese and Kazakh universities.This long-term initiative is meant to encourage stronger Chinese-Kazakh ties, as President Nazabayev encouraged stronger cultural ties between both nations as China continues to expand BRI. In 2018, the service was expanded as the Chinese Embassy provided Eurasian National University and Zhas Ulan Republican School with 'Chinese Langauge' classrooms, equipped with textbooks, computers and software to facilitate learning in Chinese.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020160816ec8g009q1&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://theproreview.co.uk/education/china-and-kazakhstan-the-foremost-of-the-one-belt-one-way/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kz.chineseembassy.org/rus/dszc/emba/t1625680.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Eximbank provides a $34 million USD export buyer's credit loan for the acquisition of Huawei equipment
description: On November 8, 2007, the Export-Import Bank of China and Kazkomemrtsbank JSC signed an export buyer's credit loan agreement to finance Kazakhstani mobile operator Mobile Telecom Service LLP's purchase of equipment from Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. The loan carried a maturity period of seven years and a flexible schedule of repayment, based on the profit generated by the project. The loan sought to further the development of Mobile Telecom Service's Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM) network. Mobile Telecom Service was a new GSM-operator in Kazakhstan that provided its services under the trademark 'NEO.' Commercial start of its network took place February 14, 2007; its network covered 45 cities in Kazakhstan in 2007, with plans to expand to 84 by the end of that year (see 'Kazkommertsbank JSC (Kazakhstan) performed as organizer of loan...'). In 2007, 51% of Mobile Telecom Service was owned by Kazakh state-owned Kazakhtelecom JSC (see 'New Kazakh Operator Mobile Telecom Service Secures US$34-mil. Loan from Chinese Bank'). It appears that Kazkommertsbank JSC then used the proceeds from the export credit agreement to on-lend to Mobile Telecom Service LLP (see 'Kazkommertsbank JSC (Kazakhstan) performed as organizer of loan...').
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=RIAORE0020071115e3bf0030f&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=WDAN000020071115e3bf0000v&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.kase.kz/news/show/1036055, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $776,900 USD to support education in Kazakhstan
description: In 2008, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, provided $776,900 USD to support education in Kazakhstan. The donation included funds to finance the study of 77 Kazakhstani students at the China University of Petroleum (Beijing) and 35 students for study in Kazakhstan (see pg.38 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008'). STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as 'Completion' because it is evident that the funds were totally disbursed to the fund. AidData has assumed that 'contributed' meant donated/granted; the language implies that this money went beyond scholarships, so the flow type was coded as 'Grant' and not scholarships. 'Year uncertain' was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2008.

title: China National Petroleum Corporation provides $1.35 million USD to set up a scholarship for Kazakhstani students to study in China
description:
On September 27, 2004, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) signed an agreement with the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan in which CNPC agreed to provide $1.35 million USD to the ministry for the creation of the "Presidential Scholarship." The scholarship was to finance higher level education in China for excellent Kazakhstani students (see "Support for Education in Kazakhstan"). The scholarship fund was active as of September 2011 (see "Китайская Национальная Нефтегазовая корпорация (CNPC) - это").

STAFF_NOTE: "Project status" was coded as "Completion" because CNPC stated in 2008 that it had "provided" the $1.35 million USD, implying that all Chinese funds had been disbursed (see pg.4 of "CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008").

title: CDB provides $200 million USD loan via $650 million USD credit line to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan (Linked to Project ID#59136, #53574, and #53572)
description: On March 17, 2015, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $650 million USD credit line agreement with the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK), as captured by linked project ID#53574 (see pg.67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). The credit line was intended to finance projects in the sectors of energy, transport, infrastructure, manufacturing, information technologies, agriculture, and other sectors. The credit line aimed to finance joint Kazakh-Chinese and other projects (see pg.107 of 'BoP and External Debts 2016'). The maturity date of each loan made under this loan agreement was June 15, 2025 (see pg.67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). In June 2015, DBK drew down $200 million USD from the credit line (see pg.47 of 'Annual Report 2015'). The intended use of these funds is unclear. The interest rate was initially 5.7% (see pg.F-185 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). The loan's interest rate was changed from fixed to floating in 2016 (see pg.65 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). In 2016, DBK drew down $170 million USD for unspecified purposes, as captured by linked project ID#53572 (see pg.65 and 67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). Then, between December 31, 2016 and June 30, 2017, DBK drew down an additional $80 million USD for unspecified purposes, leaving the credit line with $200 million USD remaining, as captured by linked project ID#59136 (see pg.67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). STAFF_NOTE: While the interest rate has changed, in the absence of the current floating rate, AidData has elected to keep 5.7% as the coded interest rate.
sources: https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dbk.kz/upload/iblock/ed6/ed6ac0af95e1030652f131a159ff8b7a.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since there is no specific location that received money from the credit line and multiple areas may benefit from this agreement

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $7.5 billion USD syndicated loan for the Kazakhstani Section of Line A and B of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (Linked to Project ID#39997, #40833, #39955, #54528, and #70616)
description:
The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, also known as the China-Central Asia Gas Pipeline ,or, simply, the Asia Gas Pipeline, is a 1,873-km long gas pipeline connecting Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, delivering gas equal to approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption. It consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D). A, B, and C run parallel to each other. The pipelines begin at Gedaim on the Turkmen-Uzbek border, run through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and end at Khorgas in China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Line A (#40833 and #54489) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines — Line B (ID#40834 and #54489) and Line C (ID#39997) — started their operations in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (ID#39955 and #70616), which is under construction, will run through Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Kyrgyzstan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C provide 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介").

JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) with China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline in Kazakhstan. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each held a 50% equity stake in AGP (see pg.37 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus”).

This project records the financing of the Kazakhstani segment of Lines A and B, which are sometimes referred to as parts of the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. Project ID#39997 records the financing of the Kazakhstani segment of Line C. Line A and Line B begin on right bank of the Amu Darya River, near Turkmen-Uzbek border, before passing through central Uzbekistan and south Kazakhstan (see “中国-中亚天然气管道简介”). Construction of the Kazakhstani section of the pipeline commenced on July 9, 2008. As of October 20, 2012, all compressor stations along Line A and Line B of the Central Asia–China Gas Pipeline were operational, enabling the pipeline to transmit 30 billion cubic meters of natural gas annually (see “Flow of natural gas from Central Asia”).

In October 2008, AGP entered into a $7.5 billion USD syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) to finance the development, construction, and operation of lines A and B of the pipeline. The loan facility bore interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + 2.15% per annum during the guarantee period and 3-month LIBOR + 2.9% per annum thereafter. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in March 2013 until October 22, 2023. The amounts due under this loan were secured by account charges, a pledge over deposit certificate agreement, an insurance assignment, and a guarantee from CNPC. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount from this loan was $4 billion USD (see pg.110 and 151 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus” and pg.84 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus”). Based on this information, interest rate was recorded as the 3-month LIBOR in October 2008, 4.059%, + 2.15%, or 6.209%, while grace period was 4.5 years, the repayment period was 10.5 years, and the maturity period was 15 years.

STAFF_NOTE: Line A and Line B are sometimes referred to as the 'first and second phases of the construction of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline.'
sources: https://kase.kz/files/emitters/KZTG/kztgf9e1_2017.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://center.cnpc.com.cn/bk/system/2017/12/07/001671340.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://kase.kz/files/emitters/KMGZ/kmgzf4_2018_eng.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://kioge.kz/en/34-interview/35-interview-2010, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.kmg.kz/uploads/documents/reports/2008/eng/God_othcet_2008_EN.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/g0lany8wv8oxwxc/Flow%20of%20natural%20gas%20from%20Central%20Asia.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/csffs2azkwj43j0/Experience.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Coded up to the country level since teh gas would be beneficial to the whole country.

title: China National Petroleum Corporation provides ¥5 million CNY to help Kazakhstani students attend university
description:
In 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation's (CNPC) Kazakhstan project companies spent ¥5 million CNY to help finance the education of Kazakhstani youth at prestigious universities in China, Kazakhstan and other countries (see "CNPC in Kazakhstan").

STAFF_NOTE: Because there are several CNPC subsidiaries in Kazakhstan and it is unclear which one financed this project, AidData has elected to code CNPC as the funding organization. It appears that CNPC was providing scholarships, so the flow type was coded as such. "Project status" was coded as "Completion" because it is clear that the Chinese funds were clearly disbursed. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it was not confirmed that this flow was committed to in 2010.

GEO_notes: Coded up to the country level. The money provded was to help students study in Chinese inversities with no specific districts menitoned as the one students were from.

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $1 million USD for a special education fund to support Kazakhstani students
description: In 2000, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, set aside $1 million USD for a special education fund to support young Kazakhstani experts, excellent students, and talented students from poor families (see pg.38 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008'). The funds were provided under a memorandum of economic cooperation between CNPC and the Akimat of Aktobe region. The education of 50 Kazakhstani students at China University of Petroleum - Beijing were covered under the funds from this fund, as were the education of another 11 students at Kazakhstani and Russian universities (see 'Seven Years of Honest Co-Operation'). STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as 'Completion' because it is evident that the funds were totally disbursed to the fund. AidData has assumed that 'set aside' meant donated/granted; the language implies that this money went towards a scholarship fund, meaning that it was not a scholarship itself. Therefore, the flow type was coded as 'Grant.' 'Year uncertain' was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2000.
sources: https://www.cnpc.com.cn/cnpc/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://csr.cnpc.com.cn/cnpccsr/xhtml/PageAssets/CNPCinKazakhstan2008en.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://economic-definition.com/Companies_of_China/Kitayskaya_Nacional_naya_Neftegazovaya_korporaciya_CNPC__eto.html, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://web.archive.org/web/20190227054434/http://www.investkz.com/en/journals/39/150.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/ru/gysy/hjysh_common.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Coded up to the country level. The money provided was for an education fund to support Kazakhstani students to allow them to study in china

title: China Development Bank provides a $218 million USD loan to KazNurTel LLP for the CDMA-450 Network Expansion Project
description: On July 4, 2005, China Development Bank signed a $218 million USD loan agreement with KazNurTel LLP for a CDMA-450 (Code Division Multiple Access) Network Expansion Project. This project sought to provide trunking systems and internet access to rural areas in Kazakhstan (see 'Development Bank of China to grant a loan for digital trunking of rural regions in Kazakhstan'). The project facilitated the sale of CDMA-450 telecommunications equipment and the provision of related technical support and after-sale services from Shenzhen Zhongxing Telecom Equipment Corporation (ZTE) to KazNurTel LLP. KazNurTel LLP was a Chinese-Kazakh joint venture (special purpose vehicle) for the manufacture of telecommunications equipment and provision of related services, in addition to the installation of CDMA networks. ZTE owned 49% owned of its shares (see pg.54 of 'Interim Report 2005'). The remaining 51% was owned by the Government of Kazakhstan (see pg.39 of 'Chinese Economic Presence in Kazakhstan').
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=OANA000020050704e174000rt&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.zte.com.cn/mi_imgs/global/investor_relations/352963/P020120918590194505716.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://journals.openedition.org/chinaperspectives/pdf/4053, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://www1.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/sehk/2005/0902/00763/ewp112.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: The CDMA-450 Network Expansion Project is designed to provide wireless to all of Kazakhstan. There was no information about more granular locations so it was coded up.

title: China Eximbank provides a $172 million USD loan for the acquisition and assembly of 152 locomotives in Kazakhstan
description:
On December 29, 2002, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $172 million USD loan agreement with Kazakhstan Temir Zholy (also known as National Company Kazakhstan Temir Zholy) — the national railway company of Kazakhstan — to finance the acquisition of new 152 Chinese locomotives (see "KAZAKH RAILROAD TO GET $172 MLN FROM CHINA'S EXPORT-IMPORT BANK"). The loan covered approximately 86% of the $200 million USD cost of the locomotives. The loan carried a maturity period of 14 years, a grace period of 4 years, and an interest rate of 5.6% (see "State monopoly Kazakhstan railway will enrich locomotive depot due to credit"). This loan did not receive a sovereign guarantee from the Government of Kazakhstan (see "KAZAKH RAILROAD TO GET $172 MLN FROM CHINA'S EXPORT-IMPORT BANK").

Prior to this project, Kazakhstan Temir Zholy had not renewed its locomotive depot for eight years (see "State monopoly Kazakhstan railway will enrich locomotive depot due to credit"). The China Northern Locomotive & Rolling Stock Industry Corporation provided the locomotives: two Dong Feng diesel locos with General Electric traction packages were to be imported from China, while another 150 were to be assembled in Shu in the Jambyl Region by 2009 (see "Realities and costs drive Kazakhstan's railway reform").

STAFF_NOTE: The exact signing date is ambiguous; it was signed by December 29, 2002, when it was announced at a management meeting, but it is unclear if it was signed at that meeting. AidData has assumed it was for coding purposes.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=weklb00020030102dycv0000m&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://kase.kz/en/news/show/143009/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://web.archive.org/web/20200908055732/https://www.railwaygazette.com/in-depth/realities-and-costs-drive-kazakhstans-railway-reform/29097.article, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: It was coded up to country level because there is no information on where the locomotives went in the country. Some were assembled in Shu District but did not stay there.
name: Kazakhstan

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas donates 80 apartments in Aktobe to World War II veterans (Linked to Project ID#73474)
description:
On May 9, 2003, Victory Day, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, donated 80 apartments it had purchased in the city of Aktobe to veterans of World War II (see "Seven Years of Honest Co-Operation"). 80 Soviet Army veterans - many widowed and lonely - were the beneficiaries of this donation. The building was located in a prosperous part of Aktobe (see "中国石油中亚油气合作项目履行社会责任纪实"). All of the apartments were located in a single 80-apartment residential building (see "Seven Years of Honest Co-Operation"). 

CNPC AMG also set aside $63,700 USD to subscribe the veterans to newspapers and magazines (see pg.41 of "CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008"). CNPC AMG was still spending that amount every year as of 2017 (see "Oiling the wheels of cooperation"). For this project and its subprojects, see linked project ID#73474.

STAFF_NOTE: Some sources claim that the donation was made in 2001; however, the majority specifically state that the handover of the apartments came on Victory Day in May 2003, which is what AidData has coded here.
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/v4o69gn9u3rd7wh/Kazakhstan.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://web.archive.org/web/20190227054434/http://www.investkz.com/en/journals/39/150.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.panoramakz.com/index.php/archive?y=2007&n=16, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://online.zakon.kz/Document/?doc_id=30163802#pos=3;-52, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://csr.cnpc.com.cn/cnpccsr/xhtml/PageAssets/CNPCinKazakhstan2008en.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/ru/sqjs/hjysh_common.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://gas.in-en.com/html/gas-527971.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.chinadailyhk.com/articles/15/118/35/1494217696175.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.cnpc-amg.kz/?p=smi_16, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/OverseasCommunities/common_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.cnpc-amg.kz/?p=smi, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: The ChinaDaily source reports that the 80 apartments are in Atkobe City.
name: Kazakhstan

title: CDB provides $80 million USD through a $650 million USD credit line to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan (Linked to Project ID#53574, #53572, and #53573)
description: On March 17, 2015, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $650 million USD credit line agreement with the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK), as captured by linked project ID#53574 (see pg.67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). The credit line was intended to finance projects in the sectors of energy, transport, infrastructure, manufacturing, information technologies, agriculture, and other sectors. The credit line also aimed to finance joint Kazakh-Chinese and other projects (see pg.107 of 'BoP and External Debts 2016'). The maturity date of each loan made under this loan agreement was June 15, 2025 (see pg.67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). In June 2015, DBK drew down $200 million USD for unspecified purposes, as captured by linked project ID#53573 (see pg.47 of 'Annual Report 2015'). In 2016, DBK drew down $170 million USD for unspecified purposes, as captured by linked project ID#53572 (see pg.65 and 67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). As of December 31, 2016, DBK had drawn down $370 million USD (see pg.F-100 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). Then, between December 31, 2016 and June 30, 2017, DBK drew down an additional $80 million USD, as captured by this project. The credit line was left with $200 million USD remaining. The loan details and purpose of this $80 million USD tranche is unclear (see pg.67 of 'Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017'). STAFF_NOTE: AidData created this project to capture the drawn down amount not accounted for specific loans, not the entire credit line, which is captured by project ID#53574. There was $200 million USD remaining in the credit line that had not been drawn down as of June 30, 2017; therefore, $450 million USD had been drawn down. The $370 million USD is accounted for in linked projects ID#53573 and #53572; this project captures the $80 million USD that was drawn down but has not been connected to a specific project. Additionally, because the $370 million USD had been drawn down as of December 31, 2016 and $450 million USD had been drawn down as of June 30, 2017, the $80 million USD captured by this project must have been drawn down between those dates in 2017, hence the commitment year. The maturity period was coded as eight years because this loan was agreed to in early 2017 and matured in June 2025.
sources: https://old.nationalbank.kz/cont/BoP_2016_eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dbk.kz/upload/iblock/ed6/ed6ac0af95e1030652f131a159ff8b7a.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.rns-pdf.londonstockexchange.com/rns/0289Y_-2017-11-30.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The Development Bank finances projects across the country. Becasue I could not trace the loan to a specific project, I coded up to the country level.
name: Kazakhstan

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $63,700 USD for newspaper and magazine subscriptions for World War II veterans (Linked to Project ID#73474)
description: On May 9, 2003, Victory Day, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, set aside $63,700 USD to subscribe Kazakhstani veterans of World War II to newspapers and magazines (see pg.41 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008' and 'Seven Years of Honest Co-Operation'). CNPC AMG was still spending that amount every year as of 2017 (see 'Oiling the wheels of cooperation'). This project captures CNPC's purchase of subscriptions in 2008. Linked project ID#73474 is the umbrella project for the newspaper and magazines subscriptions. Below is a list of projects that capture the money set aside for the subscriptions for every year from 2003 to 2017. - 2003: Project ID#73487 - 2004: Project ID#73488 - 2005: Project ID#73489 - 2006: Project ID#73490 - 2007: Project ID#73491 - 2008: Project ID#73492 - 2009: Project ID#73493 - 2010: Project ID#73494 - 2011: Project ID#73495 - 2012: Project ID#73496 - 2013: Project ID#73497 - 2014: Project ID#73498 - 2015: Project ID#73499 - 2016: Project ID#73500 - 2017: Project ID#73501
sources: https://www.chinadailyhk.com/articles/15/118/35/1494217696175.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://csr.cnpc.com.cn/cnpccsr/xhtml/PageAssets/CNPCinKazakhstan2008en.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://web.archive.org/web/20190227054434/http://www.investkz.com/en/journals/39/150.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Project #73472 outlines 80 apartments that were donated to WWII soldiers in Atkobe City. It says that these same veterans also are the recipients of the newspaper subscriptions. For this reason, I coded this donation to the city (ADM2)
name: Kazakhstan
